s.text: The very president of the United States has put the case in these terms--Joe Camel, declares Bill Clinton, tells minors that "smoking is cool."

This long-running campaign (which has helped the brand become the world's most popular) portrays a disciplined man of experience who seems to embody a cowboy code of honor, a traditional regard for women, and the offer of a self-sacrificing friendship with other males who can meet his standards of what it is to be a man.
Perhaps he's next on the FTC's hit list.
In the end, Mayakovsky is stuck in a kind of zoo, where curious people come to watch him do unhealthy things.

Anyway, if Joe Camel hasn't much in common with Marlboro's John Wayne West, he has plenty in common with a literary creation who is becoming more relevant every day.
